Summary: Barbara Fish, M.D., is currently Della Martin Professor Emerita of Psychiatry and Biobehavioral Sciences at UCLA. Dr. Fish was born in New York in 1920. She graduated from Barnard College in 1942, and from NYU College of Medicine in 1945. Prior to beginning her work in Child Psychiatry under Lauretta Bender at Bellevue (1950-55), she completed two-year residencies in medicine and in pediatrics and a one-year rotation in adult psychiatry; in addition, she trained for five years at the William Alanson White Institute of Psychoanalysis. Dr. Fish held academic appointments at Cornell University Medical College before returning to NYU and Bellevue in 1960 as Associate Professor and Director of Child Psychiatry and head of the new Children's Psychopharmacology Research Unit, funded by the National Institute of Mental Health. She became a full Professor in 1970 and moved to the UCLA Neuropsychiatric Institute in 1972, becoming the Della Martin Professor in 1989. Dr. Fish is best-known for her longitudinal studies of infants born to poor and to schizophrenic mothers, following two cohorts of children from birth into their fifties and defining a specific complex of developmental deficits, pandysmaturation, which could be linked to schizophrenic symptoms later in life. In addition, she conducted some of the earliest well-designed trials of neuroleptic drugs in very young children, developed a descriptive typology of children's disorders, predating the DSM-III, and contributed extensively to the literature on children with serious psychiatric disorders.

Summary: Joel Elkes (1913-) was born in Germany but received his medical education at the University of London and the University of Birmingham (UK), where he established the first Department of Experimental Psychiatry in 1951, two years after completing his MD. He emigrated to the US in 1957 to become Director of the Clinical Neuropharmacology Research Center at NIMH and later held professorships at Johns Hopkins, McMaster University in Ontario, and the University of Louisville. He is recognized as a founder of psychopharmacology and conducted the first published blind controlled trial of a psychoactive drug at Birmingham in the early 1950s, with his late wife Charmian Elkes.

Description.note: The interview is organized topically with a loose chronology, beginning with a brief outline of Lasagna's early education and continuing on to discuss his work with Henry K. Beecher at Harvard University in the early 1950s; his leadership of the Division of Clinical Pharmacology at Johns Hopkins University; chairmanship at the University of Rochester; work with the Center for the Study of Drug Development; and deanship of the Sackler School of Graduate Biomedical Sciences at Tufts University.  Most of the interview deals with issues relating to drug evaluation and experimentation, including informed consent; blinding; problems of pain assessment; placebo response; pros and cons of the randomized clinical trial; patient selection; use of narcotics and narcotic antagonists in medicine; LSD experimentation; FDA drug evaluation and the Drug Efficacy Study of the 1960s; development of the NSAIDs (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs); and methods of pain management, including acupuncture.|~|Dr. Lasagna's papers are archived at the University of Rochester.
Summary: Louis Lasagna was born February 22, 1923, in New York City.  He earned his BA at Rutgers University in 1943, received his M.D. from Columbia University in 1947, interned at New York City hospitals, and spent two years as a Research Fellow at the Anesthesia Research Laboratory at Massachusetts General Hospital.  From 1954 to 1970, Dr. Lasagna was on the faculty of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, where he started the first academic group devoted solely to clinical pharmacology.  In 1970, he was appointed the first Chairman of the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry; and in 1984, he was named Dean of the Sackler School of Graduate Biomedical Sciences at Tufts University, the position he held at the time of the interview.  While at the University of Rochester, he founded the Center for the Study of Drug Development, which moved to Tufts in 1984.  Dr. Lasagna was internationally recognized as an authority on clinical trial methodology, analgesic and hypnotic drugs, medical ethics, and the placebo effect.  He served as a consultant to the Food and Drug Administration and to several other government agencies.  He was also well-known for his modern revision of the Hippocratic Oath, adopted by many medical schools.  He died in 2003.

Description.note: Chapter 3 of a report on guidelines for the investigation of new drugs for anxiety and depression, prepared by an ACNP Task Force under contract from the FDA Division of Neuropharmacological Products.  Recommended changes of FDA guidelines for testing anti-depressant psychotropic agents; Discussion of Phase II and Phase III studies including objectives, subjects selection, sample size, setting, investigators, design, dosage, trial duration, assessment, and interpretation; Outlines problems with Maintenance Studies and Long Term Trials, as well as strategies researchers can use to mitigate them.
Summary: Gerald Klerman was the Chair of the Guidelines Task Force.  Dr. Klerman was born in New York in 1928.  He graduated from Cornell University and received his MD from NYU Medical School; completed a residency at Harvard and a research fellowship at NIMH.  From 1966 to 1970, he held professorships at Yale and at Harvard.  Klerman served as head of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration (ADAMHA) from 1977 to 1981, under President Jimmy Carter.  He then returned to academia as professor of psychiatry and vice-chair of research at Cornell Medical College and New York Hospital.  He died in New York in 1992.
